programme.title: Count Abdulla
programme.desc: Comedy series about twenty-something British-Pakistani Muslim doctor Abdulla Khan. Something's not right as Abdulla feels out of it and has developed inexplicable allergies and insatiable cravings at work - meanwhile, his mysterious bus stop assailant Kathy is looking for him as she's worried that she may have passed something on that could spread around the community. After coming face-to-face with a stray piece of garlic naan, it's starting to become clearer what ails the junior doctor - Abdulla is left with little time before Kathy catches up with him when a quasi-religious ceremony goes wrong, so it might be up to rude-boy cousin and wannabe Shafi to save the day.

programme.title: Dodo
programme.desc: Wickedly sharp animated series about the dramas and pitfalls of secondary school. When Fran asks Joe to perform with her in the drama club showcase, Joe accepts not realising that it will involve singing - Joe has vowed to never sing on stage again ever since a disaster in the Year 2 nativity play. Joe tries to get out of the performance in various ways, but all of them fail - desperate, he then complains to Frisbo and Pete about how he thinks the showcase is stupid and doesn't want to do it. When Fran overhears and tells him that he doesn't have to do it if he doesn't want to, she's clearly hurt but Joe doesn't notice - after Joe sees Fran struggling to do the performance alone, Lily helps him realise that Fran wanted him on stage with her because he's her friend and not because he's a good actor. Joe then jumps in to save the day...

programme.title: Dodo
programme.desc: Wickedly sharp animated series about the dramas and pitfalls of secondary school. Joe is looking forward to spaghetti bolognese for dinner, but his mum says she forgot to buy an onion and can't make the dish without it - Joe therefore steps up and volunteers to go the supermarket to buy an onion, but his family all laugh because nobody believes he can do it without getting distracted. Joe decides to prove them wrong and makes it his mission to buy the onion - all is going well at the supermarket until he sees that his favourite cereal is on special offer. Joe thinks that he can afford both, but it turns out that he miscalculated and only has enough money for one of the - when he buys the cereal, Frisbo comes to the rescue and guides him to the discount aisle where he finds pickled onions that he can afford. Joe is about to leave the supermarket victorious... but then he sees Lily and Hitesh together and this causes him to trip over his trolley and smash the jar of pickled onions.

programme.title: The Only Way is Essex
programme.desc: Reality series following the lives, loves and scandals of a group of real-life Essex guys and girls. As Ella's infamous voice note becomes the talk of the Caribbean, Dan and Amber stand defiant and manage to keep their cool, but will Ella's surprise arrival in the Dominican Republic cause temperatures to soar, and will Dan take the opportunity to finally get to the bottom of her accusations? Meanwhile, Amy is devastated that she and Billy will be spending their one-year anniversary on different sides of the world, but when there's a surprise knock on her hotel door, will Amy know she made the right decision to stick with Billy? Elsewhere, it seems that new lad Jordan has had one girl on his mind, but when he finds out that Ella's arrived on the island, will he make the move to make her his girl?

programme.title: The Only Way is Essex
programme.desc: Essex is a small place, and Dani knew it was only a matter of time before she would have to come face to face with the Great Gatsby now he is back from LA - will they have an amicable first meet when the time comes, and will news that Dani and Roman have shared a little more than friendly advice destroy the chances of any reconciliation? After Jordan set Ella's heart ablaze with his vocals in the Dominican Republic, he has been prepping for his first date back in Essex with her ever since, but will Ella's commitment issues leave Jordan wishing that he had never bothered, or could this be the start of something special for the pair? After a heart-to-heart and getting everything off their chests in the Dom Rep, will Amy and Billy find it easy to get back on track and a slice of salsa dancing relight that spark for them, or will it create another opportunity for yet another argument? Finally, Brockett reflects that now might be time to let bygones be bygones with Saff... will she agree?

programme.title: The Media Show
programme.desc: A row over comments by a British MP has reignited debate about who we see in adverts. Sara Denby from the University of Oxford and Dino Myers-Lamptey from The Barber Shop agency share their views on how the industry has changed. In the US, major streaming companies are merging as they compete for global audiences. Camilla Lewis, chief executive of Curve Media, explains what this could mean for both producers and viewers. Historian Bettany Hughes returns with Treasures of the World on Channel 4. She talks about filming around the globe, how history programmes are made today and why stories from the past still attract big audiences.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: The latest news from the BBC.

programme.title: Ukrainecast
programme.desc: After an EU decision on the use of frozen Russian assets to aid Ukraine was postponed until December, discussion among European leaders returned to plans for a ceasefire this week. And the latest example of so-called nuclear 'sabre-rattling' by Vladimir Putin, forced Donald Trump to respond with a vague commitment of his own to resume US nuclear testing for the first time in decades. On this edition of Ukrainecast, Jamie Coomarasamy and Vitaly Shevchenko are joined by BBC Verify's Olga Robinson and senior digital journalist Laura Gozzi, to answer your questions. Could Denmark and Sweden police the Baltic Sea? What happened to the Russian dam targeted by Ukraine? And are Russians facing discrimination from authorities in Europe?

programme.title: Lethal Waters: Climate Change in Pakistan
programme.desc: The BBC followed the path of floods in Pakistan, from the mountains of the north to the plains of the south, and discovered a country trapped in an endless cycle of humanitarian crisis and recovery. The devastation takes different forms in every region, but there is one thing in common: the poorest are the ones paying the biggest price for global warming.

programme.title: Unspun World with John Simpson
programme.desc: John Simpson, in discussion with the BBC's unparalleled range of experts across the world, analyses Donald Trump's approach to dealing with China, examines the United States' rivalry with China in South East Asia, and explores what the future holds for Benjamin Netanyahu and the Israeli government.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: The latest news from the BBC.

programme.title: AI Decoded
programme.desc: AI Decoded investigates the integration of artificial intelligence and drone technology and the real world impact happening today. AI powered drones are now used across a whole swathe of industries, whether it be on the battlefield, for agricultural purposes, search and rescue missions, delivery and logistics, the list goes on and on. In this episode, AI correspondent Marc Cieslak meets with UK Defence contractor BAE Systems who have recently developed a prototype AI drone that can be controlled using voice commands. In an exclusive for AI Decoded we trial the drone and discuss the implications this new AI development could mean for everyone.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: The latest news from the BBC.

programme.title: Global Eye
programme.desc: A new weekly programme from the BBC World Service, bringing you forensic journalism from all corners of the world by BBC Eye, the World Service’s critically acclaimed investigative unit, and featuring expert global correspondents taking you to the heart of the biggest international stories. In this week’s episode we explore the rise of gen Z protests around the world. The Eye team uncovers what really happened during the popular youth uprising that led to the downfall of Bangladesh’s former prime minister Sheikh Hasina. Sammy Awami is in Madagascar, where another wave of political unrest driven by gen Z anger and frustration toppled President Andry Rajoelina.

programme.title: Talking Business
programme.desc: Can Argentina’s economic reforms make a lasting difference, and do they hold any lessons for the rest of the world? President Milei’s latest election win gives him a mandate to continue with his sweeping spending cuts on everything from pensions and healthcare to fuel subsidies, but do they finally mean an end to years of economic crisis? Former head of Argentina’s central bank Guido Sandleris explains the role of foreign trade and what it could mean for other parts of Latin America. Plus, the president of leading business lobby group the Institute for Business Development of Argentina, Santiago Mignone, tells Ben Thompson why the changes could bring the foreign investment that leads to sustainable growth.

programme.title: Sharpe
programme.desc: Napoleonic War-based action-adventure. Winter 1813 - Wellington is informed by the debonair Comte de Maquerre that Bordeaux is ready to rebel against Napoleon, but Wellington's spymaster Ross is suspicious and tests Maquerre by suggesting that they use Maquerre's own castle as a base. Maquerre reluctantly agrees but says that the castle is in Napoleon's hands, so Wellington appoints Colonel Bampfylde to lead the attack on the castle with Sharpe in support. Bampfylde, who is intent on glory, sends Sharpe on a scouting mission and tries to capture the castle on his own, but he fails and casualties are heavy - Sharpe, who is a witness to the carnage, therefore has Harris and Frederickson sneak into the castle in disguise, and they soon force the French to surrender once inside. Ashamed by Sharpe's victory, Bampfylde sends him off on a reconnaissance mission - however, Sharpe soon discovers that Bordeaux has no intention of rising against Napoleon and that Maquerre is a double agent.

programme.title: Sharpe

programme.desc: Drama series set in the 1950s and adapted from the novels by James Runcie. As Gary Bell waits to discover his fate, Sidney is determined to stand by his side. Sidney hurries to the station, where he finds his friend with his knuckles bruised and Eddie dead on a stretcher. programme.title: Grantchester
programme.desc: Drama series set in the 1950s and adapted from the novels by James Runcie. programme.title: Long Lost Family
programme.desc: This episode follows one woman searching for her Jamaican-born birth father and another on the hunt for the half-brother that her mother gave up for adoption after his American serviceman father went home and off the radar following the Second World War. In our first case, Rachel Burch grew up in a white family and stood out in the small West Sussex village where they lived - she turns to us for help finding her Jamaican-born birth father, but she's also yearning to find any family member whose lived experience has been like her own. Our second story concerns Sue Davis, whose mum had a baby boy from a relationship with an American soldier that she met working in a wartime canteen in Winchester - afraid of rejection, she asked Sue not to look for her son until after her death. Now, years later on from this request, Sue duly takes up the search on behalf of her late mother.

programme.title: Midsomer Murders
programme.desc: Members of the Midsomer-in-the-Marsh Ornithological Society fall out when one of them, Ralph Ford, claims that he has spotted a blue-crested hoopoe - the sighting puts him ahead in a list competition, but MMOS president Patrick Morgan says that the bird could never have been seen in Midsomer as it is native to Uganda. Ralph storms out of the meeting infuriated - the next day Patrick is found dead in Swansdown Lake, the scene of the alleged hoopoe sighting, and his body is pulled from the lake entangled in a mist net used to catch and release birds. The dead man's wife Nina, a former Russian prima ballerina, had recently become pregnant - before his death Patrick Morgan accused Nina of sleeping with another man and professed it to be impossible that she was pregnant. Was Patrick's obsession with ornithology really to blame for his death, or something more sinister? Barnaby and Jones attempt to discover the truth.
